steps.label: What is a résumé for?
desc: A résumé is a summary of the information in your CV that matches the job you are applying for. It gives information about your education, qualifications, skills and work experience. It should be no more than one page.
This model is an example of how you might structure your résumé if you are applying for your first job.
It is advisable to check with a teacher or tutor if there are any special conventions you should use.
Also look at the covering/cover letter.

steps.label: How is it structured?
desc: Below is the framework that was used to create this résumé.

steps.label: Personal information
desc: Provide your college or temporary address if you have one, as well as your permanent address.
There is no need to mention your age, gender, nationality, race, religion or marital status. Don't send a photo unless you are asked to.

steps.label: Objective
desc: Summarize your goals and customize your résumé for specific positions. Your objective should be stated in terms of a realistic short-term goal and/or a job for which you are currently qualified.

steps.label: Profile
desc: Your profile gives an employer an idea of who you are.

steps.label: Education and qualifications
desc: These are shown in reverse order and do not include information about elementary school.
You should try to include American equivalents of your qualifications.

steps.label: Work experience
desc: This is also shown in reverse order, beginning with the most recent. As this is the résumé of a recent graduate it includes holiday and part-time work.

steps.label: Skills
desc: These are the practical abilities of the applicant. The section also includes any formal qualifications relating to these skills.

steps.label: Interests
desc: This is a short section. It includes things like sport, creative activities and community activities, but not vague subjects such as 'reading' or 'travel'.

checkList.text: Collect together all the information you need to include in your résumé.
Select information that is relevant to the job you are applying for.
Make sure all the information is accurate.
Use action verbs and adjectives to present yourself positively.
checkList.tellMeMore:
Action verbs

Use action verbs to describe your achievements and make them look more dynamic.

Examples: achieved, administered, advised, analysed, arranged, compiled, conducted, coordinated, created, designed, developed, devised, distributed, evaluated, examined, executed, implemented, increased, instructed, introduced, liaised, managed, mentored, monitored, negotiated, organized, oversaw, prepared, recommended, reduced, represented, researched, solved, supervised, trained

Positive Adjectives

Use positive adjectives to describe yourself.

Examples: active, adaptable, committed, competent, dynamic, effective, efficient, enthusiastic, experienced, flexible, (highly) motivated, organized, professional, proficient, qualified, successful

Show Education and Work experience in reverse order, beginning with the most recent.
Use either full sentences (e.g. I taught French at a summer school) or note form (Taught French at a summer school).
Describe your work experience in terms of self-motivation, teamwork, organization, problem-solving, and enthusiasm.
Have I kept my résumé short? (for new graduates not more than one page)
